Thank you, Madam President. Firstly, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Fava, for his hard work in reaching an agreement with the Council on a common position that includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this directive, we have demonstrated once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The objective of this directive is clear: to combat the mafias, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.
We want to eliminate unfair minimum wages for immigrants that also distort average wages especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, and hospitality.
This measure requires great courage and political will since there are many interests created and a lot of money moving in the submerged economy.
In precisely difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migration flows intelligently, with generosity but also with responsibility.
It would be tempting not to try to tackle an economy that is submerged.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave some 8 million irregular immigrants in a state of vulnerability with labor conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this activity to be effective, it is necessary to have strict inspections and economic sanctions, and even criminal penalties in the most serious cases, which have a deterrent effect on businesses.
We will succeed in reducing the burden on the economy and cutting off the migratory incentive that generates the possibility of working irregularly.
It must be made clear that the only option to work in Europe is the legal way.
Therefore, we want to continue with the global approach and ask the Commission - Mr Barroso, Commissioner - to present as soon as possible the new blue cards for other categories of workers.
Dear colleagues, Mrs Ferrero-Waldner, Mr Solana. I would like first of all to thank the three rapporteurs for their work. And as shadow rapporteur on the report on the EPAs, I will refer to

To this report specifically – starting by congratulating Mr Saryusz-Wolski on the result of his work and for the collaboration he has offered to the other groups in order to achieve a consensus outcome.

In the same way that this Parliament has claimed on numerous occasions that the European Union should arm itself with the necessary tools to speak with one single voice in the world, so too must the European Parliament show unity when it comes to assessing and promoting the EU's major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The commitment of our Group – the Socialist Group – has gone in two directions. On the one hand, to introduce or reinforce important issues that are key to us across the board in external policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

Peace everywhere on planet Earth or a commitment to human development? On the other hand, proposing elements of balance between the geographic priorities of the PES with respect to how they originally appeared in the text – whether they appeared or introducing them as new elements if they were absent.
We have argued, for example, in favor of greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional frameworks and cooperation involved in the Eastern dimension, defined recently.
We have defended greater diversity and greater relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent which we often only remember when there are particularly violent wars, and even then, not always.

In relation to Latin America, we have wanted to reflect the current processes of negotiation of association agreements, the first of their nature in a bidirectional relationship that will bring the European Union into its entire history.

In respect to the Mediterranean, we have resorted to a reductionist approach which only talks about security in order to include in exchange all the rich acerbo-political, economic and social content contained in the Barcelona process.

As for the amendments for plenary, our group has not tabled any, believing that in some way this strengthens the balance achieved with the compromises, and therefore we will be opposing most of the amendments so as not to weaken the commitment reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
The Venezuelan referendum has been hailed as a victory of the 'Yes', elegantly acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

There has been no equality of opportunities in the campaign and officialism has received the overwhelming support of all state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coactions.
Even under those conditions, the country has remained practically divided in two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with just one of them.
The European Union should promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not through physical attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralist and free path.

In that sense, we criticize the decision of the Venezuelan government to expel a Spanish Eurodiputado and even more so the way in which such an expulsion was carried out, but we make a call to this House to avoid
That our representatives make declarations in their visits to third countries that violate local legislation in force and, even less, insult a head of state just because he or she may be critical.
With this attitude, we are committing future EU missions to other countries.

Mr President, I have just arrived in Venezuela where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral observation mission for the referendum held on 15th April last year.

European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with a global positive assessment of the process regarding its organization, transparency, participation, exercise of free and secret voting rights, and security at all stages.

The statements made by Mr. Herrero on Venezuelan television indicate that they were attempting to invalidate the current electoral process in Venezuela, which involves serious allegations against democratic institutions in that country, as well as interfering with the internal politics of an independent nation.
Our Parliament should not facilitate any type of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be proper for the honourable Member to provide explanations to this House about an action which has an impact on all of us.
The Committee on Budgets believes that it is of utmost importance to have a clear classification of each budgetary instrument.

Therefore, the most realistic option seems to be the creation of a new instrument for actions distinct from public aid for development in countries that fall within the scope of application of this regulation.
From a budgetary point of view, it seems inappropriate to propose financing from the Development Committee since this money does not exist although
The English translation of the provided Spanish speech is: 'There are no lines for a number of years with credit allocated on a multiannual basis. There is credit for 2009 but not further.'
In any case, given that the financing of this new cooperation instrument has to be compatible with the financial framework 2007-2013, it is appropriate to
Remember the importance of the mid-term review of the financial framework, which should allow adjustments to be made to the maximum limits of the different headings.
Madam President, this is late on a Monday evening; probably the Commission has other things which it is more concerned about than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a report from the Commission, a report on the application of Regulation (EC) No 864/2007, 2001.
Council Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 of 28 May 2007 on the cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States in the area of the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in an area which is really not Community-related; it is an intergovernmental area, where the Council has tried, through the regulation, to stimulate cooperation between those judicial bodies.
However, in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That means that certain measures have been foreseen, such as the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc., but I acknowledge that it is quite difficult for the Commission to take action.

I do not know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but I find it quite difficult to achieve it due to the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.
We are asking judicial authorities who collaborate with one another—27 countries worth, authorities who manage 22 different languages and distinct legal systems—and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has noted that the results are not good, there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and naturally we do not have the means to do so.
The ideal would be to have material means.
For example, what could the Commission do to provide judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, with technological elements such as videoconferencing systems?
The videoconference may be an utopia in many small judgments of the European Union as a whole, but it seems to be the only way to do so.
The European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We would need to reinforce this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, all training for judges is essential.
This is something that the Commission cannot do on its own.
However, the Commission can encourage the development of such training courses in EU law and knowledge of the different legal systems.
There is an enormous difficulty which is the language problem, that is, how one can communicate. Let us take a Spanish judge and a Finnish judge; two languages are very different.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to manage their own law, which is already complex per se, should be required to have knowledge for this type of activity.
What can we do from a practical point of view to facilitate the judges' task of interpretation and translation?
What could we do to help you do that?
In presenting this report, I should like to express no harshness or rigor towards the Commission.
I believe that the work is quite difficult.
What I would like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have here a Commissioner who is interested in this topic, what does the Commission think it can do to be able to make greater progress?
Adhere strictly to this regulation of 2001, which is somewhat vague and voluntary in nature, and I do not know if it can have any practical consequences or whether it can be implemented.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative period with the final adoption of the last maritime package.

However, I would like to remind you that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident – the Erika near the French coast – which gave rise to the first package of legislative proposals aimed at preventing accidents.

We believed we had conjured up the danger, but soon afterwards the coasts of Galicia were devastated by the 'Chapapote', coming from another accident even greater than the first one: the sinking of the ship.

Since then, in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, we have worked on successive legislative packages trying to overcome the excessive resistances that we found in arms manufacturers, oil companies, classification societies and also in certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

In these ten years we have adopted different Directives and Regulations, some of which we have had to go back over because, as a result of the cuts made by the Council in its first draft, they were not effective in their initial version.

We adopt the rules for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Union disaster fund for major oil spills, ports of refuge, and now we review and adopt the liability of passenger transport by sea, the investigation of accidents.

Maritime traffic, the European Union system for tracking and information on maritime traffic, the control by the port state of the port, and finally the regulation and directive concerning inspection organizations and the recognition of ships.
And all this is good and desirable that it may enter into force as soon as possible for all the Member States.
Therefore, I feel satisfied.
But at the end of the legislature, I leave Parliament with the regret that we have not succeeded in making the introduction of control systems mandatory that exist.
They are patented to know when and how many tons of fuel oil have been illegally dumped into the sea by a certain ship.
That is to say, a kind of black boxes or tachymeters which can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a ship arrives at port.

We should pay more attention to the marine environment and take more severe measures to reduce the amount of pollution we produce, as this will affect our food chain and our lives, resulting in us paying a high price.
I trust that it will not take another ten years to more effectively and efficiently control illegal maritime traffic.
The revision of the Eurovignette Directive is an issue of great importance that concerns us all, especially the peripheral countries which we feel are the victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to tackle the external costs of road transport by introducing three new charges: atmospheric pollution, acoustic pollution and congestion.

While the principles underlying the proposal – "who uses pays" and "who pollutes pays" – are reasonable, the proposed solution is in no way discriminatory towards a sector that has been suffering from the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonization of road freight transport, or what was not the objective, has resulted in the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is inappropriate and far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transport, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European companies that employ thousands of people.

Three areas in the European Union that contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer, a consumer who will see how their products are encased by the application of these taxes.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable and environmentally friendly transport system, without neglecting roads, because currently it is the only way to reach every part.
The transition remains an unattainable dream.
The European networks, the maritime autoparts, the cross-border knowledge, still in some cases projects and not reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the Titanic of the global economy goes down, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing and much less for joy.

The European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and Parliament recommending the establishment of a strategic association between the European Union and Mexico.
The European Council for External Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13th last year, pending Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us remember that at the seventh meeting of the joint European Union-Mexico parliamentary committee, which was celebrated at the end of October last year, we said that one
Strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes an essential impulse to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We pointed out the good moment for relations between both parties and the positive balance of the existing global agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen political, economic, and cooperation collaboration to the maximum in response to new challenges of all types arising from the financial and economic crisis that shakes our continents.

With the great country that Mexico is, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equality, consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Therefore, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the strategic association between the European Union and Mexico, which will be submitted to Parliament tomorrow.
I would like to congratulate all rapporteurs on their excellent work regarding the report on microfinance.
They have undoubtedly improved the Commission initiative.
The recommendations established here will allow us to develop an authentic framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector – a sector that
What has been successful in many developing countries, including some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as an instrument to improve social inclusion and job creation?

However, it had not yet been transferred to the sector or community context. I believe this is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
In that sense, strengthening the initiatives that are being advanced here is a priority, but we need to take further steps.
There is a need to increase the funds available for this microfinance support structure.
There needs to be greater availability for individuals and companies that do not have access to credit, and in this regard, I would like to highlight, Mrs President, the example of the
The European microcredit guarantee as an instrument to facilitate access which has been included in the report.
I conclude by thinking that this will undoubtedly lay the foundations for creating a harmonious framework in the European context that will promote the microcredit sector.

Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to discuss the budget and to consider how we can ensure that the support for coal, which is an indigenous energy source, continues beyond next year.

And I say this with due respect because, in an unprecedented manner, a high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed himself to be opinionated in the opposite direction, filtering it through an economic publication.
Nada de eso.
There will have to be continued support after 2012 for my country's coal, and I want that to appear in the diary of sessions.
Please limit yourself, gentlemen officials, to complying with the current plan, and then starting from 2012, with the instrument that we begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Mr President, Mr Barroso, this question, as explained by Mr Bowe, is very timely given the diplomatic conference on the recycling convention for ships which will take place in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr Blokland not just for the question but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of combating the bad practices and methods that are being used to harass ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brokland's motion for a resolution. However, there are some points that worry us.

The first one is the paragraph three, which has been already pointed out by him as well, that says that vessels in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, they should be within the scope of application of the Basel Convention.

We tabled an amendment on this paragraph because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Vassilieva agreement must be taken into account and not go against it, but it should be the future international agreement on ship waste that defines the details of its implementation.
The motion for a resolution also requests in point 14 a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

We really seem to be somewhat impatient to talk about mandatory contributions at this time when we have not yet decided within the LaOHM what system will be adopted for financing it, and I do not think that either the European Commission has a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point fifteen, it is stated that the Commission should establish clearly that the State with jurisdiction over waste is responsible.
We do not believe that it should be up to the Commission to decide this matter, which must also be decided in an international convention.

It is important to ensure consistency in the future convention on ship recycling and the巴塞尔 Convention on the Control of Transboundary movements of hazardous waste and its elimination, taking into account not only the巴塞尔 Convention but also all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this report and express our appreciation for it, because in times of economic crisis it is essential to maintain a programme such as this one, which has clear positive social effects.
We should send a clear political signal that in these times of economic uncertainty, from Brussels to Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned with or solely focused on.

We should not be solely focused on recovering the financial system but we must also be fully aware that social policies, especially those that support the most vulnerable members of our European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program should continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy – here we agree with the Commission – because European agriculture has a strong social character, because it is an instrument that works, because now more than ever is needed, and because it must continue to work.

The Socialist Group, as well as the rapporteur, are opposed to this programme being cofinanced between the European Union and the Member States because it would lead to discrimination among the states according to their wealth, with the result that the programme might not be able to be implemented in the countries most in need.

It is not understood that now, when more is needed, the Commission wants to save EU money in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that every year there are excess budgetary revenues in the agricultural budget.
Full EU financing is fundamental for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries, especially those in greatest need.
The 43 million potential beneficiaries of this programme call for greater effort, and in no case should budgetary savings be made.
Austerity, yes, but not with the poorest.
It is precisely to ensure that it reaches all citizens of the Member States that the programme must cover the entire range of distributed foodstuffs.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have tabled an amendment so that all distribution costs, including transport, storage and administrative costs, should be covered by EU funds.
We also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be of Community origin and of high quality.
It is the consistent stance maintained by this Parliament in other similar programmes that we have recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the school fruit distribution plan.
Nothing more. Thank you very much.
We hope that the Commission takes into account the position of this Parliament when it votes and, above all, that the plan be put in motion in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.

The consequences of exploiting its natural resources without restrictions would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and for the indigenous population but also for the world as a whole.

The melting of extensive areas has put these risks on the agenda currently, which makes it necessary to have a new global regulation to protect the Arctic similar to the one that already exists for Antarctica, taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty among all parties involved, including, undoubtedly, the European Union, is necessary to protect its single environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of human activities of all types, and regulate multilaterally navigation along the new maritime routes that become accessible.
The Arctic Council has been a model of cooperation for managing common problems throughout its existence.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we should raise the spirit and assonance to prevent states in the area or other international actors from falling into strategic fiascos, forgetting what should be the common objective - the preservation of a great shared tradition.
Mr President, unlike the two speakers who have just spoken before me, I agree with most of what has been said by the other participants.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive aimed at protecting interpreters.
When speaking about seeking a more intelligent way of doing business, what is really being said is that we should do away with intellectual property.
Because it is only possible to do business if there is established law.
We already have an established right at national level?
The Commission, under the direction of Mr McCreevy, has adopted a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe that this House should approve the commitment that we have reached.
Achieved in the context of the Committee on Legal Affairs, thanks to the work of the rapporteur Mr Crowley and the various shadow rapporteurs such as Mrs McIllwain and Mr Tugendhat.
I believe it is a magnificent directive, one that will enhance the creation of intellectual property.
In addition, this directive includes several recommendations regarding the continuation of work.

I believe that the adoption by this House of this report, and I hope that the Council will align itself with the lines of the Council, the Commission and Parliament, will serve to ensure that in the next legislative period the

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to Parliament, and move forward in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.
The information you give me is correct, but the impression we have as European parliamentarians - and ultimately, European citizens - is that there is a very dangerous gap in EU law.
At this time, as the fiscal requirements in each of the member states become stricter, mobility is almost impossible.
The reason for the pragmatic approach adopted by the Commission is that it has never received support from the Council.

We are in a vicious circle, where the Commission refers back to the Council, and the Council refers back to the Commission, but meanwhile, citizens who live in this Europe we want to build do not have the opportunity to live in different countries and establish relationships as a result of the heavy fiscal burden that may arise from the lack of tax harmonisation.
Fiscal. Can the Council do something to help us get out of this vicious circle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that it is not the title of Mr Tajani who has come, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a European Parliament member.
And as an European parliamentarian, I know that we have experienced frustration about the application of EU law.

Now in Parliament we tend to get involved with the Commission. I think that what we are asking the Commission is an impossible mission because all Community law and the application of Community law is based on the indirect application.

The commission has very few staff in its central headquarters where it receives some complaints and has some possibilities of action but at this time, in addition, there is a tendency to limit budgetary powers, with which the commission will not have the possibility of doing so.
All EU law and its application is based on the action of national authorities: national parliaments, national courts, national officials.
In this respect, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we have to do is help the Commission, and I think that there are some points in Mrs Frassoni's report that could be useful in order to achieve this application.
I refer to those related to the correlation of Directives, the cooperation of national Parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr President, two years ago on a mission led by my colleague and fellow Group member, Mrs Marián, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and of being present in this court and of being conscious of the immense work that this court was doing not only for Sierra Leone but for all of humanity.
The Special Court in Sierra Leone has, as has already been said here, set a precedent.

A precedent because, as well as indicating in the resolution, it is the first international tribunal financed by voluntary contributions; it is the first court established in the country where the alleged crimes took place; and it is also the first court, as has already been mentioned, in which a former prime minister has been judged.

Therefore, not only because it sets a precedent but also as a reference for other tribunals that have taken inspiration from it, such as those in Rwanda, Serbia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we consider it imperative to adopt this resolution, on which we have been working jointly with the tribunal for several months now.
Two years ago we adopted a resolution to support its financing. Two years ago the Tribunal was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of
Money and did not have sufficient support. We must also thank the European Commission, which financially supported this court.

We therefore request primarily that those sentenced serve their sentences. The issue at stake is no longer just the functioning of the court, which concludes this year, but rather the legacy it will leave us. Secondly, of course, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
In conclusion, the Special Court in Sarajevo is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country in this planet is giving us, in which, when entering the court, we could see a slogan written that said: “Without justice, there is no peace”.
And precisely because of that, we have the moral obligation, not only as Europeans but also as human beings, for this legacy of this court to remain permanent in history.

Thank you, Mr President. In brief, I will thank your excellencies at this time. Mr Vice-President of the Commission, thank you once again because you have demonstrated it, as you did in the third package.

Maritime, that your impetus, your political category has been capable of promoting an agreement close to the Council, and making it possible for Parliament, the Council and the Commission to agree at this stage, in these latter days when the legislature ends.
I believe we have to congratulate ourselves.

I would undoubtedly like to express my gratitude for the close cooperation received from the shadow rapporteurs, both in the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

Thank you and I repeat, the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs. And finally, I believe that we will adopt an agreement at first reading on such an important regulation which undoubtedly completes the work of the

Third maritime package means success for this Parliament and for the European Union in the three institutions and justifies once more the co-decision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all European citizens.
Sorry, I was one minute late; however, I would like to respond to the Commissioner, who is aware of my friendship with her and my affection for Mr Orban.
But the Commissioner has not said a single word about the recommendation of the People's Defender.

The Advocate General, who is aware of all the arguments that have been presented to us by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation, which the Commission appears to be ignoring in every possible way.

I do not want anyone to disagree with me, including Ms Cunéva, because it is clear that she does not have the data. However, all the data she has given me are in line with what we knew and with what the people's defender also knows, and he does not tell us whether these data effectively show

Despite all that, and as the defender of the people who knows this recommends that the rule be changed, does it tell us if the Commission is going to adopt what the defender of the people asks for and what the Parliament recommends according to what the defender of the people has asked?

Mr President, I believe that the proposals for regulations submitted by the Commission are important and necessary, and it was also important and necessary for the PPE Group to table them in good time.
We should insist on the principles that have been insisted upon by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr Swiebel and Mr Deprez, and it is the principle of Community competence.

It is a matter of Community competition where, for practical reasons, it is convenient to maintain certain competencies of the Member States but, as Mr Barroso has said, limited in terms of their scope and time.
Community competences are unavailable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the power to abandon those Community competences.

Established this, it is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow the adoption of this package of measures in first reading.

But also I hope that from the Commission side in the successive we can make progress in the preparation of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as highlighted by Mr Söderman in his last intervention.
We are talking about problems that affect people more directly, and to the extent that we are able to solve those people's problems, people will realize that the European Union has a function.
Finally, Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr De Brueyere and Mrs Swiezka, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to cooperate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and asked to speak on this platform because I was a witness to what they called an expulsion, but which in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague, Luis Herrero.

In addition, I can observe that persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of opponents, threats, disrespect for human dignity, and the manipulation of justice are all common occurrences in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the drop that has tipped the bucket, which gave rise to this resolution, but there are thousands of cases as heartbreaking as his own that are cited in the resolution and others that are not cited.

The case of Iñigo Odebrecht is an example. He was born in a humble Caraqueño neighborhood of Petare, which is well known for its danger, and he also voted for a mayor who was not part of the Chavista regime.
Eigio studied with the help of others, specifically with City Bank, and was able to establish his own business, the Caracas Bank. He also lived a normal life helping those in need.
However, today he is serving his sentence in a Chinese prison, legally, after having been detained for two years without any ongoing charges.
Their only crime is to be part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Niso Moreno, student leader at the University of los Andes, elected several times to the university council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won in the 2010 elections to the Federation, current Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is accused of murder in a state of frustration, violent acts committed passively, despite having been exonerated of all accusations.

Situations like hers are the daily life in this country where persecution against adversaries with the aim of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissidence has become an everyday occurrence.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy, despite the difficulties I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office in the elections.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all this progress, the South of the Union is burning and is burning more and more.
Therefore, the resolution that has been tabled in this Parliament cannot be just another resolution intended to highlight our great concern about foreign aid.
Wildfires occur due to various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And with independence of the responsibilities that could exist in some states or in some autonomous communities, what is certain is that this Parliament has to clearly call on the Commission to act quickly and to put all the resources at its disposal, which are not few, within its reach.
Victims, the damage suffered, and the need for reforestation are not understood in terms of bureaucracy, nor can they understand budgetary deficiencies.

There is a need to prioritize and act, and in this case, that means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimizing preventive policies in the best possible way, demanding that they be achieved.

In that case, responsibilities to the states that fail to comply with them. However, assuming that this is not a problem of some Southern European states and that climate change does not affect only a few states, it affects everyone and is a common cause.
Therefore, one of the main tasks that this Parliament has ahead of it must be to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the next Copenhagen Summit.
'Hotspots', 'to minimize emissions of winter gas', 'because they are obviously at the root of wildfires', 'and these in turn are part of the causes of more climate change.'
Therefore, adopting this resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without any doubt.
But that it should be fulfilled is the Commission's challenge, if truly, Mr Commissioner, you want to avoid the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Thank you very much for giving me the floor, Mr President. I would like to address Mr Barroso.
Barroso, I have been following your work with great interest and respect for a long time now, ever since you were in charge of a country very close to our hearts, which is Portugal.
I must say, however, that now I am absolutely surprised by you.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have demonstrated disdain towards the group in which I am present - the group of non-inscribed members - by not giving us even one minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens, and you have demonstrated contempt for all our voters.

Madam President, Commissioner, you finished your words by telling us that there was a crisis in the dairy sector but you started by saying that you had taken all the measures and that things were being solved.
Mira, rectificar es de sabios.
That is a well-known Spanish saying that could be applied very well to the case we are dealing with today.

The dairy sector has been suffering from one of its worst crises in history for months now, and despite this, some governments, including my own, the Spanish Government, are refusing to move back on decisions made at the CAP health check.
Such decisions were adopted without taking into account the fragility of this sector, in a market context very different from that which emerged after the agreement was closed.
The Member States either did not wish to see or were unable to see the storm that was approaching at that time.
The reform was abandoned in a short time due to the large swing in the market, which shows that the sector is totally exposed to price volatility.

That large producers such as France and Germany – countries that achieved the largest increase in their national production quotas under that agreement – should now be asking for a revision of the decisions taken during the audit gives much food for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States made a mistake and should have listened more carefully to the voices among us that were calling for the decision on the future of the sector to be postponed until 2011.
It is a pity that it was not heard.
Do it now.

Thank you very much, Mr President. I would like first of all to congratulate Mrs McGuiness on this initiative, which highlights the important role that the CAP plays in responding to the needs for food supplies at international level.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the EU budget, it must be said very clearly and at the highest level that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food security should certainly be. And in previous decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food security is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot be compared with other sectors in the economy that can thrive in a free market because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union in order to move his business forward, and the EU needs the farmer again in order to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and high-quality food for an increasingly demanding citizen.
Therefore, I believe that there would have to be a change in direction of the CAP, but not its disappearance.

It would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers in addition to restoring a management policy for agricultural markets that provides greater stability in prices, which would have a positive impact not only on farmers but also on consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to promote balanced relationships between the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, there is a need for an information policy for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with EU legislation on media.

Madam President, from the European Parliament I want to pay tribute today to all women. Although we have come a long way since that March of 2011 when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that gender equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone for permission, but in many cases they continue to be paid less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
It is also important to remember women in rural areas whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality that we must continue to denounce is violence against women.
There has been an excessive number of women killed this year alone, not to mention the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to physically or psychologically harm them.
It is time to say 'enough' and to say it loudly and clearly.
I repeat my commitment to the European victims' order and to the directive on victims presented by the Commission, which will be put to the vote, if God willing, in June next year.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you that maternity continues to be an obstacle for women's progress, and I believe this is a trend that should change.
I want to send a message of hope. Many women, with the help of increasingly more men, we have to move forward on the path towards equality, opportunities, rights, and also duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still much to be done.

European social model, which we assume does not just focus on our pension systems, education or healthcare, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employer and employee within companies.

The labor reform that the Spanish government has approved without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and moves us away from the objectives of the 2020 strategy, both in terms of job creation as in terms of the quality of employment.
A labor reform by itself does not create jobs; it is economic growth that creates jobs.
What makes a labor law is defining under what conditions workers enter companies, in what conditions they remain within them, and under what conditions they leave them.
With this reform, where 80% of workers will be unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they could be dismissed due to a decrease in companies' income, or
They could unilaterally modify their schedules; what is clear is that workers will enter the labor market with greater insecurity, remain there with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which is aimed at the European social model and which prioritizes the competitiveness of Spain's economy in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike, such as the one that is being called for tomorrow in Spain to defend this social model.
